[ ] read “deepwork” by cal newport 
[ ] read ["the art of learning"](https://www.amazon.com/Art-Learning-Journey-Optimal-Performance/dp/0743277465)
[ ] go through again [learing how to learn](https://www.coursera.org/learn/learning-how-to-learn)
[ ] read "thinking in systems"

[Study part time, work full time](https://medium.com/launch-school/tips-on-studying-part-time-at-launch-school-7bf1fd97b79e)

[additionally supplementary books](https://medium.com/launch-school/my-list-of-books-resources-for-ls-students-72e468c41188)



study habits and tools: advice from [AMA](https://medium.com/launch-school/another-ama-with-a-launch-school-capstone-graduate-6478df4f5d4c)

- internalize that launch school is a long progress (1-2+ years) which is a good thing because you can build good study habits along the way. Start with one habit, and then add one each month. 
- study every single day
- accept that some days might not be your best programming days
- explain difficult concepts outloud or in writting.  Create a 'today i learned' repository and keep track of what you learn every day. 
- set a goal of hours each week to study
- when studying prioitize studying deeply & deliberately (phones off, etc)
- [create a script for problem solving in interviews](https://jzerwick.svbtle.com/why-you-need-an-interview-script)
- <details><summary> use anki </summary>
  
  + [Article on using anki](http://augmentingcognition.com/ltm.html)
  + You can use Anki to learn & remember everything.
  
  + Make each card as small as possible (atomic); they have to be easy to remember.
  + Practice everyday.
  + Keep all your cards in one deck; that will ensure that you review everything consistently and shuffling the subject matter will also improve your ability to recall material.
  </details>
- skim the material first and then start from the top and read again more thoroughly
- repeat the problems that you answered incorrectly and only those. focus you time on the problems which gave you the most trouble. 
- summarize the material you just learned and look into `mind-mapping`.
-
